Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development and Evaluation of a Miniature Coaxial Ion Trap Mass Analyzer for Portable Chemical Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Drs. Nicholas Taylor and Kristina Lemmer at Western Michigan University and Daniel Austin at Brigham Young University are working to develop a novel miniaturized instrument for field-portable chemical analysis based on a powerful method known as mass spectrometry. Specifically, the team seeks to develop a device capable of more detailed and yet faster analysis than is currently possible in field-portable analyzers. The ability to provide industry and the scientific community with a simple, lightweight, and portable tool capable of rapid in situ chemical measurements can have a societal impact on many areas including biochemistry, pharmacology, environmental monitoring, threat detection, industrial monitoring and quality control, as well as planetary exploration. The work is being conducted by undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and aerospace engineering, including members of underrepresented groups. This cross-disciplinary collaboration resonates with NSF’s goal to enhance convergence research while inspiring and helping train the next generation of scientists and engineers.

Field portable systems equipped with highly miniaturized ion trap mass analyzers will possess the ability to rapidly and reliably make quantitative chemical measurements of a wide range of molecular species. The novel coaxial ion trap being designed and build by the Taylor team utilizes a rectilinear ion guide (RIG) for efficient injection of internally or externally generated ions into a high capacity simplified toroidal ion trap (STorIT) for ion accumulation and storage. Ions of analytical interest stored in the toroidal trapping region are mass selectively injected into a cylindrical ion trap (CIT) nested within the toroidal trapping ring. The process of spatially isolating ions for MSn analysis can be repeated for a range of species without having to repopulate the toroidal trapping region, enhancing analytical efficiency. Since a single mass is injected into the CIT for MSn analysis, there is an inherent reduction in chemical noise which enhances the device’s detection limits and identification confidence. The system is being modeled and experimentally evaluated through a collaborative effort between Western Michigan University and Brigham Young University. Three target applications will allow testing of key performance features: rapid analysis of suspected illegal drug powders, sensitive detection of tracer compounds used in natural gas and petroleum wells, and characterization of semi-volatile compounds in atmospheric aerosols.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ideally, field portable systems equipped with highly miniaturized ion trap mass analyzers will possess the ability to rapidly and reliably make quantitative chemical measurements of a wide range of molecular species. Tandem mass spectrometry (MS2) capability is also highly desirable. MS2 with a single ion trap typically isolates a single species for detection while discarding the remaining ions, resulting in low analytical efficiency. An increase in chemical measurement speed and efficiency can be realized by utilizing two miniaturized ion traps, one high-capacity trap for ion storage and a second trap for MS2 analysis.

The miniature simplified coaxial ion trap (SCIT) mass analyzer developed from this effort is composed of a rectilinear ion guide (RIG), a simplified toroidal ion trap (STorIT), and a cylindrical ion trap (CIT) nested within the toroidal ion trap. The developed SCIT utilizes a RIG for smooth and efficient injection of internal or externally generated ions into a high capacity STorIT for ion accumulation and storage. Ions of analytical interest stored in the toroidal trapping region are mass selectively injected into a CIT for MS2 analysis. The process of spatially isolating ions for MS2 analysis can be repeated for a range of species without having to repopulate the toroidal trapping region. Since a single mass is injected into the CIT for MS2 analysis, there is an inherent reduction in chemical noise which enhances the devices detection limits and identification confidence.

A prototype of the proposed SCIT was thoroughly modeled and experimentally evaluated through a collaborative effort between Western Michigan University and Brigham Young University. Experimentally, the RIG and STorIT trapping regions were first characterized. The trapping capacity of the STorIT was evaluated with xenon and found to have a total ion capacity in excess of 2.5x105 ions, confirming toroidal trapping geometries possess higher trapping capacity compared to linear traps with equal trapping volumes. The ion trapping efficiency of the STorIT component was also evaluated. The xenon ion population within the STorIT component was measured as a function of storage time. It was found that a slow ion leak resulted in an exponential decrease in xenon ion population over time. While the primary mechanism for this ion loss is not currently understood, it is believed to be due to the unique asymmetric trapping field created at the RIG-STorIT intersection point where significant higher order multipole fields may create regions of instability resulting in ion losses. Characterization of the STorIT concluded by evaluating the mass selective ejection resolution and efficiency. An organic mixture of toluene, toluene-D8, and o-xylene was used to mass selectively eject ions m/z = 91, 98, and 106 from the STorIT trapping region. Ejection efficiencies of ~100% and mass ejection resolution of Dm = 4 amu was found when using an ejection signal of 2.5 Vpp. Lower ejection signals improve ejection mass resolution (Dm = 2 amu) but with reduced ejection efficiency while higher ejection signals only broaden the mass ejection resolution (Dm = 7 amu at 5.0 Vpp). These experimental results are consistent with simulation results.

The fully assembled SCIT device was characterized by first examining the ion transfer dynamics between the two traps. The ion transfer efficiency was measured as the relative RF phase between the two trapping regions was adjusted and found the transfer efficiency correlated strongly with the relative RF phase. Parameters including ion mass, mass ejection signal, and helium pressure also demonstrated a dependence on transfer dynamics and transfer efficiency.

Tandem mass analysis capabilities were demonstrated using the tracer compound perfluoromethylcyclopentane (PMCP). The m/z = 181 ion fragment was mass selectively transferred into the CIT were MS2 analysis was conducted. The resulting MS2 spectra confirms the SCIT device functions as designed and performs relatively consistent with modeling predictions. Additional compounds were examined throughout this project including SF6, perfluoromethylcyclohexane, and perfluorotributylamine and demonstrated the system possesses a reasonable mass range, selective mass transfer, MS2 spectral resolution, and detection sensitivity. Results from these compounds provided preliminary observations for future analytical assessment of the fully optimized SCIT device.

The ability to provide industry and/or individuals with simple, lightweight, and portable tools capable of rapid in situ chemical measurements can have a societal impact on many areas including biochemical, pharmacological, environmental, threat detection, industrial monitoring and quality control, as well as planetary exploration. The development of these tools can have a profound impact on the way first responders, nurses, doctors, law enforcement officials, as well as industrial workers carry out their tasks. The work reported here was conducted by undergraduate and graduate students in both chemistry and aerospace engineering. This cross disciplinary collaboration is well suited with NSF’s goal to enhance the growing convergence of research. It is the hope that this work will recruit and inspire the next generation of scientist and engineers alike, with an emphasis on women and underrepresented minority groups.
